APPLICATION CHNJC 60235 S1872-2067(24)60235-4 10.1016/S1872-2067(24)60235-4 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 The proposed reaction mechanism of CO2-ODHE over the Zn x ZrO catalysts. Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. (b) The partially enlarged XRD patterns of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. (c) Raman spectra of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. Fig. 3 HRTEM images of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. (a,b) ZrO2; (c,d) Zn0.02ZrO; (e,f) Zn0.05ZrO; (g,h) Zn0.1ZrO; (i,j) Zn0.2ZrO; (k–n) Zn1ZrO; (o,p) ZnO. Fig. 4 Zn K-edge XANES (a) and phase-uncorrected FT-EXAFS (b) spectra of Zn foil, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts (The EXAFS spectra have been obtained by transforming the corresponding k 3 χ(k) EXAFS function). Fig. 5 XPS spectra of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. (a) Zr 3d; (b) Zn 2p; (c) O 1s. Fig. 6 CO2-TPD profiles (a), Py-IR spectra after desorption at 200 °C (b) and NH3-TPD profiles (c) of ZnO, ZrO2, and Zn x ZrO catalysts. Article Synergistic sites over the Zn x ZrO catalyst for targeted cleavage of the C–H bonds of ethane in tandem with CO2 activation Wenjun Qiang a 1 Duohua Liao a 1 Maolin Wang b Lingzhen Zeng b Weiqi Li a Xuedong Ma a Liang Yang a Shuang Li a * Ding Ma b * a School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi’an 710069, Shaanxi, China School of Chemical Engineering Northwest University Xi’an Shaanxi 710069 China School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi’an 710069, Shaanxi, China b Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences, College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering Peking University Beijing 100871 China Beijing National Laboratory for Molecular Sciences, College of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China * Corresponding author 1 Contributed equally to this work. The CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (CO2-ODHE) provides a promising way to produce ethylene and utilize CO2. Simultaneous upgrading of ethane into the high value–added chemical products and the reduction of greenhouse gas CO2 emissions could be achieved. However, the targeted breaking of the C–C/C–H bonds of ethane is still a challenge for the designed catalysts. In this paper, ZnO-doped ZrO2 bifunctional catalysts (Zn x ZrO) with different Zn/Zr molar ratios were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method, and the functions of various sites for CO2-ODHE reaction were revealed by in situ characterizations and ethane pulse experiment: the medium-strength acidic Zn-O-Zr sites are responsible for the purposefully cracking of ethane C–H bonds to ethylene, while the more oxygen vacancies (OV) created by the introduction of Zn2+ are responsible for the efficient activation C=O bonds of CO2, thus promoting the RWGS reaction. In addition, the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic performances, with C2H6 conversion, C2H4 yield, and CO2 conversion about 19.1%, 10.5%, and 10.6% within 5 h, respectively (600 °C, GHSV = 3000 mL/(g·h)). Especially, the initial ethylene space-time yield of 355.5 μmol/(min·g) was obtained under 6000 mL/(g·h); Finally, the tandem reaction mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS was revealed. Graphical Abstract The tandem reaction achieved by the synergistic effect of Zn-O-Zr sites and oxygen vacancies, the ethane C–H bond was selectively clipped over the Zn-O-Zr sites and the CO2 C=O bonds was activated over the oxygen vacancies. Keywords Zn-O-Zr site Oxygen vacancies CO2 Ethylene space-time yield Tandem reaction 1 Introduction Ethylene is one of the most important light olefins, not only as a raw material for the production of polyethylene, polyvinyl chloride, and other chemicals [ 1 ], but also could be used to produce ethylene glycol, ethylene oxide, and other high-value-added chemicals [ 2 ]. At present, the industrial production of ethylene is mainly through high-temperature cracking of naphtha or ethane (700–900 °C) [ 3,4 ], the whole process involves large energy consumption, carbon emissions, and high temperatures will lead to the reactor wall inevitably attached to coke, and ethylene yield and selectivity is not high [ 5–7 ]. The oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODHE) is a promising alternative process for ethylene production because it can be operated in a lower temperature range (350–600 °C) [ 8–10 ]. CO2 as a mild oxidant has the following advantages: (1) avoiding excessive oxidation of ethane to improve ethylene selectivity; (2) converting CO2 into high value-added chemicals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions [ 11,12 ] and (3) inhibiting coke by the reverse Boudouard reaction (CO2 + C → 2CO) to extend catalyst life [ 13 ]. However, the C–C bond (377 kJ/mol) of ethane is thermodynamically more easily fractured than the C–H bond (423 kJ/mol) [ 14 ], so the CO2–ODHE reaction inevitably involves side reactions such as dry reforming reaction (C2H6 + 2CO2 → 4CO + 3H2) and the cracking of ethane to carbon and methane (C2H6 → 2C + 3H2, C2H6 + H2 → 2CH4) [ 11 ]. Therefore, the ideal catalyst should target the cleavage of ethane C–H bonds to ethylene while inhibiting C–C bond breakage [ 15 ]. The catalysts are mainly divided into noble metal catalysts (Pd, Pt, and Rh) [ 16 ], transition metal carbide catalysts [ 11 ], and transition metal oxide catalysts (Cr2O3, MnO2, and Fe2O3) [ 10 ]. The Pd-doped Fe/Ni could selectively break the C–H bonds or C–C bonds to produce two reaction paths of oxidative dehydrogenation and dry reforming of ethane: the Pd-doped Fe/CeO2 reduced the energy barrier of ethylene formation and CO2 activation and increased the energy barrier of ethylene deep dehydrogenation, while Pd-doped Ni/CeO2 increased the energy barrier of C–C bonds breakage [ 16 ]. Pt and Ce species were supported on mesoporous zeolite could also inhibit the formation of CO by increasing the energy barrier of C–C bonds fracture [ 17 ]. Moreover, the noble metal catalysts (CsRu/CeO2) showed excellent carbon resistance [ 18 ]. However, the high cost of noble metal catalysts limits their wide application. Therefore, cost-effective metal catalysts for practical applications have been extensively studied. Mo2C-based materials preserve the C–C bonds of ethane to produce ethylene [ 15 ]. The oxygen-modified β-Mo2C could inhibit the cleavage of C–C bonds in ethane. The addition of Fe promoter accelerated the formation of surface oxygen species and improved the ethylene yield [ 11 ]. However, the common problem of Mo2C-based catalysts is that high C2H6 conversion and C2H4 selectivity cannot be achieved simultaneously, and such catalysts are prone to rapid deactivation [ 11,15 ]. Notably, transition metal oxides are considered to be the most advantageous catalysts due to their redox activity, abundant reserves, and low cost [ 19 ]. Among them, Cr has a variety of oxidation states, which could complete the stable redox cycles between Cr m+/Cr n+, so the Cr-based catalysts showed outstanding activity [ 20 ], while Cr6+ was discovered to selectively break the ethane C–H bonds [ 21 ]. However, Cr-based catalysts are easy to cause environmental pollution and carbon deposition [ 22 ]. Various strategies could also be used to effectively improve the activity of CO2-ODHE, such as forming solid solution [ 23 ] and spinel structure [ 24 ], changing active oxygen species [ 25 ], regulating metal valence [ 26 ] and acid-base properties [ 27 ], and supporting carriers [ 28 ]. Fortunately, Zn-based catalysts have been widely used because of their excellent performance in activating C–H bonds of short-chain alkanes [ 29 ]. The (Zn-O-Zn)2+ active sites over zeolite could not only activate C–H bonds of short–chain alkanes, but also crack C–C bonds, and control the fracture of C–C bonds by introducing K2O to adjust the acid–base properties [ 29 ]. Besides, the Zn1Co1 species anchored on nitrogen-doped carbon promoted the activation of propane C–H bonds through electronic interactions between Zn1 and Co1 [ 30 ]. It could be seen that the uniform loading of Zn species onto various carriers is the key to selectively breaking the C–H bonds of light alkanes. ZrO2 is considered to be a promising catalyst carrier due to its amphoteric properties and chemical/thermal stability [ 31 ]. In Fe1.5Ni0.5/ZrO2-M catalyst, ZrO2 selectively exposed crystal faces with higher oxygen vacancy (OV) density, the reductive OV and Fe2+-O-Zr3+ sites promoted CO2 activation to supplement active oxygen species (O*), which combine with H* from selective cleavage of ethane C–H bonds to form H2O [ 32 ]. Li et al. [ 33 ] utilized the ZnZrO x catalyst to activate CO2 and catalyze its hydrogenation to methanol, thus converting CO2 into high-value-added chemicals. They identified the Zn-O-Zr asymmetric sites as the active centers for methanol synthesis. However, the interaction between metal oxides and carriers, the active sites, properties, and mechanisms of the Zn-Zr composite oxides for the CO2-ODHE reaction were still unclear. In this study, based on the previously reported ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst [ 34 ], the active sites and the mechanism were further identified. Specifically, the application of Zn x ZrO bifunctional catalyst for the CO2-ODHE reaction was studied by in situ characterizations and other techniques to determine the effects of different sites for the ethane C–H bonds and CO2 C=O bonds: the Zn-O-Zr sites are the active centers for targeted cleaving the C–H bonds, while the OV are the sites for adsorption and activation of C=O bonds (Fig. 1 ). Furthermore, the CO2-ODHE reaction over Zn x ZrO follows the tandem mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS. This study provides a reasonable catalyst design strategy for purposefully breaking ethane C–H to produce ethylene and converting CO2 into useful resources. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Zirconyl (IV) nitrate hydrate (Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, Kermel, AR, 99.9%), Zinc acetate (C4H6O4Zn·2H2O, Kermel, AR, 99.9%) was used as the precursors of zirconia, zinc oxide, zinc-zirconia mixed oxides respectively. Ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, Damao, AR, 99.9%) was served as a precipitating agent. All of the materials were used as received without any further purification. Zirconium hydroxide (Zr(OH)4) was synthesized by a precipitation method. A certain amount of Zr(NO3)4·5H2O was dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water and stirred until completely dissolved. With the intense stirring, dilute aqueous ammonia was gradually added to the above solution until the pH value of the solution reached 8.0, and then the mixed solution continued to stir for 1 h. Then, let it stand at 110 °C for 12 h, the white precipitation was filtered and washed with deionized water until the pH was neutral, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h, The Zr(OH)4 powder was obtained. The Zn x ZrO catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. In brief, C4H6O4Zn·2H2O powders (0.2757 g) were completely dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water. Subsequently, 1.0000 g Zr(OH)4 was added to the above solution at 65 °C and stirred for 10 min. With intense stirring, dilute aqueous ammonia was gradually added to the above mixture solution until no precipitate was produced, and the precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water until the pH was neutral. Finally, the powders were dried at 100 °C for 6 h and then calcined at 600 °C for 5 h under air atmosphere (10 °C/min). The resulting sample was denoted as Zn0.2ZrO. In particular, the X in Zn x ZrO is represented as the Zn/Zr molar ratio. 2.2 Catalysts characterizations Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeretics ASAP 2020 at –196 °C. The phase composition of ZrO2, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO was investigated by an X-ray diffraction (XRD, Smart LAB SE diffractometer) using a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15418 nm) at 40 kV and 40 mA in the range of 10°–80° with a scan rate of 5°/min. Raman spectroscopy (LabRAM HR Horiba Scientific Raman spectrometer) analysis of samples was performed with a 532 nm–1 laser at ranges of 100–800 nm. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were taken by an SU8220 microscope. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) imaging was obtained by a FEI TF20 microscope operated at 200 kV. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) experiment was conducted at the Zn K-edge on beamline 1W1B at Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), which operated at 2.5 GeV with a current of 250 mA. A Si(111) double crystal monochromator was used. The photon flux at 11.58 keV was ~1010 photon/s. Data were acquired in transmission mode using ionization chambers detectors. Spectra were acquired under ambient temperature and pressure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out in Thermo Scientific K-Alpha with Al Kα (150 W, hν =1486.6 eV). The binding energies of the Zn, Zr, and O atoms were calibrated against a C 1s of 284.8 eV. Infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) was recorded using a Bruker tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer. The samples (ca. 20 mg) were placed in an in-situ cell which was heated to 450 °C in He flow (50 mL/min) and held at this temperature for 1 h. After the temperature was lowered to 50 °C, the corresponding probe molecules (pyridine) were introduced into the cell in a flow of 10 mL/min for 10 min, until the IR spectrum showed saturation of the probe molecules on the catalyst surface. 50 mL/min He flow was passed over the catalyst surface held for 30 min heated to 200 °C (10 °C/min) and scanned for 30 min. The samples were then cooled to 50 °C and scanned to generate the difference spectra presented in this report. Acid-base properties of the catalyst surface were measured by ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and CO2-TPD. NH3 or CO2 desorption profiles of all samples were obtained using a gas-phase flow reactor with an outlet flowing to a TCD spectrometer. The samples (ca. 100 mg) were loaded into a quartz tube reactor and plugged at both ends with quartz wool, heated to 600 °C (10 °C/min) in a He flow (50 mL/min), and held for 30 min. Then, after the temperature was lowered to 50 °C, the gas flow was switched to 10% NH3/He or 10% CO2/He (50 mL/min) and held for 90 min. After this pretreatment, 100 mL/min He flow was passed over the catalyst surface heated to 650 °C (15 °C/min), and held at this temperature for 120 min. Finally, the evolved gases were monitored by the TCD spectrometer. Operando Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were used to investigate the process of CO2 and C2H6 conversion over Zn0.2ZrO catalyst for the CO2-ODHE reaction. The samples (ca. 100 mg) were placed in an in situ FTIR cell which was heated to 400 °C in He flow (60 mL/min) and held at this temperature for 1 h before the temperature was lowered to 300 °C in He flow. Subsequently, the gas flow switched to the corresponding reactants. The spectra were obtained by averaging 64 scans at 4 cm–1 resolution. Thermal analyses of spent catalysts were carried out using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TP-5080) and with air acting as a reactant gas through the sample oxidizing deposited carbon. 2.3 Catalyst test The reaction of ethane with CO2 was carried out at atmospheric pressure in all experiments. 0.3000 g of the catalyst was filled into the middle of the quartz tube reactor, and then both ends were fixed with quartz wool. Before the catalytic performance test, the catalyst was activated at 600 °C for 30 min in 30 mL/min N2 gas flow. Then, the mixture of ethane, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen with the molar ratio of C2H6:CO2:N2 = 1:1:2 was flowed through the reactor at a total flow of 60 mL/min. The reaction gas flow was controlled by a mass flow controller. All the feed components and products were analyzed using an online GC (2060) equipped with TCD detectors. The conversion of the reactant was defined as: (1) Conversion (C2H6) = (X inlet(C2H6) – X outlet(C2H6))/X inlet(C2H6) (2) Conversion (CO2) = (X inlet(CO2) – X outlet(CO2))/X inlet(CO2) The selectivity of product (%) was defined as: (3) Selectivity (C2H4) = X outlet(C2H4)/(X inlet(C2H6) – X outlet(C2H6)) The yield of product C2H4 (%) was defined as: (4) Yield(C2H4) = Conversion(C2H6) × Selectivity(C2H4) The space time yield of C2H4 (%) was defined as: (5) STY (C2H4) = X outlet(C2H4)/m catalyst where X inlet and X outlet were the flow rate of the gas components at inlet and outlet corrected by the N2 flow rate (mL/min), respectively. m catalyst represented the weight of the used catalyst in the catalytic performance test. 2.4 CO pretreated experiments The Zn0.2ZrO sample was calcined at 773 and 873 K respectively with a flow of CO (15 mL/min) for 30 min. The obtained samples were labeled as Zn0.2ZrO-773 K and Zn0.2ZrO-873 K. Subsequently, the pretreated samples were subjected to a catalyst test as described in Section 2.3. 2.5 HNO3 leaching experiments Zn2+ was quantitatively removed by HNO3 leaching experiments to study the active sites over Zn x ZrO catalysts. The Zn0.2ZrO sample was immersed in 25 mL HNO3 (0.02 mol/L) solution and held at 65 °C for 24 h. Subsequently, the leached sample was washed with deionized water until pH was neutral and dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained samples were labeled as Zn0.2ZrO-24 h. Notably, the “x” in Zn0.2ZrO-x represents the pretreated time of Zn0.2ZrO in HNO3. In addition, the samples leached for 1 h, and 12 h were also labeled as Zn0.2ZrO-1 h and Zn0.2ZrO-12 h, respectively. 2.6 Pulse experiment The mechanism of reaction over the Zn x ZrO catalyst was studied by the C2H6 pulse experiment. The 0.3000 g Zn0.2ZrO sample was activated at 600 °C for 30 min in 30 mL/min N2 gas flow. Subsequently, the mixture of C2H6 and N2 with the molar ratio of C2H6:N2 = 1:3 (60 mL/min) was flowed through the reactor and held for 40 min. Then, the inlet atmosphere switched to CO2:N2 = 1:3 (60 mL/min) and held for 40 min. The whole pulse experiment was to repeat the above reaction process 4 times. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Fig. 2(a) and (b) show the XRD patterns of the prepared samples. The diffraction peaks corresponding to the tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) and the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) were observed respectively in pure ZrO2 [ 35 ], and t-ZrO2 was the main existing phase. The ZnO exhibited strong diffraction peaks appearing at 31.8, 34.4, and 36.3° corresponding to the (100), (002), and (101) planes of the hexagonal phase structure (h-ZnO) [ 36 ]. The average grain size of pure ZrO2 was ca. 12 nm, while the pure ZnO was greater than 100 nm (Table 1 ). Notably, with the addition of Zn2+, the faint diffraction peak attributed to m-ZrO2 on the Zn x ZrO immediately disappeared (Fig. 2(a)), possibly due to the presence of OV on the catalyst surface [ 31,37 ]. The OV shortened the interatomic distance of Zn x ZrO so that the cell volume of t-ZrO2 was decreased (Table 1) [ 38 ]. The diffraction peak attributed to the (101) plane of t-ZrO2 gradually strengthened (Fig. 2(a)), demonstrating that the crystallinity of Zn x ZrO was gradually enhanced and the grain size increased (Table 1) [ 31,39 ]. In addition, the (101) crystal plane of t-ZrO2 gradually shifted to a higher degree (Fig. 2(b)), which indicated that Zn2+ has been successfully doped into the ZrO2 lattice to form the Zn-O-Zr sites (defined as the strong interaction site formed by Zn2+ doping into the ZrO2 crystal surface) [ 40 ]. Moreover, diffraction peaks of h-ZnO were observed only in the Zn1ZrO sample, but not in other Zn x ZrO catalysts. It showed that appropriate Zn2+ was well dispersed on the catalyst surface [ 41 ]. However, excessive doping of Zn2+ may lead to the formation of bulk ZnO. The phase composition of all catalysts was further observed by the Raman spectrum (Fig. 2(c)). Similarly, the t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 Raman bands appeared in pure ZrO2 [ 42 ], and h-ZnO phase Raman bands were also observed on pure ZnO [ 43 ], while the m-ZrO2 Raman bands disappeared and t-ZrO2 bands were enhanced in Zn x ZrO, which is consistent with XRD analysis results. Importantly, the band position of t-ZrO2 appeared to blue-shifts (especially 309 cm–1) with the addition of Zn2+ (Fig. 2(c)), which may be caused by the shortening of the Zr–O bonds in t-ZrO2, proving that Zn2+ was embedded in the ZrO2 lattice to form the Zn-O-Zr sites [ 37 ]. The XRD and Raman results mutually verified that new Zn-O-Zr sites were generated in Zn x ZrO after Zn2+ doping. The two phonon modes at 438 and 582 cm–1 corresponded to the E2 (high) and A1 (LO) phonons of ZnO, respectively (Fig. 2(c)), where the A1 (LO) mode was believed to be related to the OV in ZnO. The relative concentration of OV was calculated semi-quantitatively by the ratio of peak intensities at 582 and 438 cm–1 (I 582/I 438) (Table 1) [ 44 ], which was gradually increased with the substitution by Zn2+ (except Zn1ZrO). The ZnO bands appeared in the Zn1ZrO Raman spectra (438 cm–1), which confirms the formation of ZnO bulk phases in Zn1ZrO. The surface morphology and element distribution of the catalysts were observed by SEM and elemental mapping (Fig. S1). All catalysts were mainly massive aggregates composed of round nanoparticles. The size of nanoparticles gradually increased from about 10 to 40 nm with the addition of Zn2+. The element mapping showed that the Zn2+ density also increased with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio. In addition, Zn2+ was evenly distributed and highly dispersed at a low Zn/Zr molar ratio, while Zn species began to agglomerate on Zn1ZrO sample, which directly proved that excessive Zn2+ doping could form ZnO clusters or massive ZnO. It is well known that the uniform dispersion of the active metal contributes to improved ethylene selectivity [ 45 ]. Therefore, the uniform dispersion of Zn2+ on Zn x ZrO may facilitate the targeted breaking of the ethane C–H bonds. The HRTEM images were used to verify the morphology and structure of the catalysts (Fig. 3 ). Both ZrO2 and Zn x ZrO samples were composed of round nanoparticles of 10–40 nm, while pure ZnO was composed of spindle nanoparticles larger than 100 nm. Additionally, the clear lattice fringes with a spacing of d = 0.314 and 0.296 nm could be measured in pure ZrO2 (Fig. 3(b)). The d value is consistent with the crystal plane spacing of m-ZrO2 (–111) and t-ZrO2 (101). However, the crystal plane spacing of m-ZrO2 was not measured in Zn x ZrO (Figs. 3(c)–(n)). Importantly, some loss of clarity and parallelism of the lattice fringes of t-ZrO2 (101) crystal planes was observed in Zn x ZrO, which may be due to the vacancy created by doping ZnO, resulting in deformation of the crystal faces [ 38 ]. No other crystal phases were observed in Zn x ZrO, indicating that the Zn sites successfully replaced the Zr sites and constructed the strong interaction sites (Zn-O-Zr sites). Moreover, spindle-shaped ZnO nanoparticles and lattice fringes of h-ZnO were observed in the Zn1ZrO sample (Figs. 2(m) and (n)), which provided direct evidence for the formation of h-ZnO bulk. The oxidation state, local coordination, and structure of samples were analyzed by XAS (Fig. 4 ). The Zn K-edge XANES spectra of the Zn foil, ZnO, and Zn x ZrO were reported in Fig. 4(a). An obviously peak at ca. 9550 eV for all Zn x ZrO samples corresponded to Hf4+, because the Zr4+ and Hf4+ cations have the same valence configuration with similar ionic radii (0.78 Å for Zr4+ and 0.76 Å for Hf4+), resulting in the local structures of zirconium and hafnium were similar close [ 46,47 ]. The edge energy position and intensity of all Zn x ZrO samples were similar to ZnO (such as peaks at ca. 9670 and 9680 eV), suggesting that the average oxidation state of Zn species in all samples is +2 [ 40 ]. In addition, the overall XANES line-shape of Zn1ZrO was more similar to the specific characteristics of ZnO (such as the post-edge peak at 9714 eV), which could also explain the existence of bulk ZnO phase in Zn1ZrO. However, the XANES spectra curves of all Zn x ZrO did not coincide with the ZnO reference spectra, indicating that the local structure around the Zn sites was different (Fig. 4(b)). All Zn x ZrO samples showed the same trend of first coordination shell peaks, which was related to O’s nearest neighbors (Zn-O coordination) [ 48 ]. Notably, although the R-space position of the first coordination shell peak of Zn x ZrO was comparable to that of ZnO, the intensity was slightly lower, which was the result of the local coordination environment change caused by Zn2+ embedding in the ZrO2 lattice and substituting part of the Zr4+ position [ 48 ]. The changes of Zn coordination environment also confirmed the existence of Zn-O-Zr sites, which were constructed due to the introduction of Zn2+. The second coordination shell peak showed an obvious difference with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio. In particular, for Zn0.2ZrO catalysts, a well-defined peak matching the position of the second-shell feature in ZnO, and its intensity was particularly obvious in Zn1ZrO, which were caused by the Zn next nearest neighbors (Zn-Zn coordination) [ 48 ]. The XPS spectra of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The peaks at 182.41 and 184.74 eV on pure ZrO2 corresponded to the Zr 3d 5/2 and Zr 3d 3/2 spin orbits of Zr4+, respectively. The peak value of Zr 3d tended to shift toward lower binding energy with the addition of Zn2+ (Fig. 5(a)), which indicated the existence of OV, and the electron density was mainly concentrated in the OV [ 49 ]. The spectral peaks of the Zn 2p corresponding to the Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2 spin orbitals were located at 1021.26 and 1044.36 eV, respectively (Fig. 5(b)). The spin-orbit splitting of the Zn 2p peaks was 23.1 eV for all catalysts, which was characteristic of ZnO [ 49 ]. This was consistent with the XANES results. The maximum shift of Zn 2p 3/2 peak in all Zn x ZrO was 0.77 eV in the direction of higher binding energy than that of pure ZnO (Table S2), which may be caused by the transfer of electron density from Zn2+ to neighboring O2– [ 49 ]. Moreover, the peak shift of Zn 2p 3/2 decreased with the gradual addition of Zn2+, indicating that the interaction between Zn2+ and ZrO2 was stronger at low Zn/Zr molar ratios [ 31 ]. In general, the peak changes of Zr 3d and Zn 2p indicated that Zn2+ replaced the Zr sites in the ZrO2 lattice to form the Zn-O-Zr sites, therefore a strong interaction between ZrO2 and ZnO [ 31 ]. The variations of surface oxygen species were studied by O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 5(c)). The pure ZrO2 and Zn x ZrO catalysts were composed of a main peak at ca. 530.26 eV and an acromion at about 531.92 eV, corresponding to the lattice oxygen (OI) and OV (OII), respectively [ 50 ]. The relative concentration of OV was calculated according to the peak area of different oxygen species (Table S2) [ 23,50 ], which was increased gradually with the increase of Zn2+, indicating that more OV was produced after doping Zn2+, and the change trend was consistent with the XPS analysis results of Zr 3d. However, the formed bulk ZnO covered the OV in the Zn1ZrO catalyst, resulting in a smaller OII peak area. 3.2 Acid-base properties of the catalysts CO2-TPD was used to analyze the CO2 adsorption capacity of Zn x ZrO catalysts and the changes in surface basic sites (Fig. 6(a) ). All catalysts showed CO2 desorption peaks at 70–240 and 395–600 °C, which corresponded to hydroxyl groups and acid-base pairs on the surface of ZrO2 [ 31 ]. The high-temperature peak area of pure ZrO2 was higher than ZnO, indicating that pure ZrO2 contained more Lewis acid-base pairs than ZnO. Moreover, the low-temperature peak of Zn x ZrO shifted to the low-temperature region, while the high-temperature peak shifted to the high-temperature region with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio, explaining that the surface hydroxyl group became unstable after Zn2+ doping, and more OV in unsaturated metal ions (Zrcus) and lattice oxygen in metal oxides (ZnO) were generated [ 31 ]. The OV has been identified as strong Brönsted basic sites for effective adsorption and activation of CO2 [ 51 ]. The concentration change of strong basic sites was quantitatively calculated according to the peak area of CO2-TPD (Table 2 ), which was consistent with the trend of the relative concentration change of OV analyzed previously. The types of acid sites and the changes in surface acidity were studied by Py-IR spectra (Fig. 6(b)). The absorbance bands of all samples at 1440, 1485, 1575, 1590, and 1602 cm–1 belonged to the strong Lewis acid sites (L), and the bands at 1535 cm–1 were associated with the Brönsted acid sites (B) [ 52 ]. The Brönsted acid sites on the Zn x ZrO gradually disappeared, and the bands of the Lewis acid sites were red-shifted with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio, suggesting that the introduction of ZnO in ZrO2 not only neutralized the Brönsted acid sites but also neutralizes the strong Lewis acid sites [ 52 ]. The results agreed well with the CO2-TPD analysis, the hydroxyl group became unstable, and the generated Brönsted basic sites (OV) neutralized both the Brönsted acid sites and the Lewis acid sites. The surface acidity was further quantitatively analyzed by NH3-TPD (Fig. 6(c)). The NH3 desorption peak of all catalysts could be deconvoluted into three peaks, attributing weak, medium, and strong acid sites, respectively [ 37 ]. The density of total acid sites on ZrO2 and Zn x ZrO catalysts decreased monotonically from 0.1626 to 0.1125 mmol/g with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio. In particular, the density of strong acid sites decreased from 0.0768 mmol/g on ZrO2 to 0.0382 mmol/g on Zn1ZrO (Table 2), which may be due to the gradual replacement of the strong acid sites Zr4+ by Zn2+. On the contrary, the density of medium acid sites increased from 0.0425 mmol/g on ZrO2 to 0.0771 mmol/g on Zn0.2ZrO, which may be related to the formation of new Zn-O-Zr sites [ 37 ]. The above trends were consistent with the results of Py-IR analysis. However, the density of medium acid sites on the Zn1ZrO decreased may be related to the formation of ZnO. 3.3 Catalytic performances Fig. 7 investigated the catalytic performance of all catalysts. It was found that the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield in the blank test were ~5% and ~2% within the initial 5 h at 600 °C, and the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield over pure ZrO2 were 2.7% and 2.6% under same condition, indicating that the ZrO2 indeed inhibit the reaction (Figs. 7(a) and (b)). A significant deactivation of ZnO was observed on the reaction time on stream (TOS), the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield gradually decreased from the initial 8.5% and 7.9% to the final 3.3% and 3.1%, respectively. Compared with pure ZrO2 and ZnO, the activity and/or stability of Zn x ZrO were improved. The C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield over Zn x ZrO changed slightly during the reaction, demonstrating that the active sites became stable after Zn2+ doping. Moreover, the doped amount of ZnO has a crucial effect on the catalytic activity, suggesting that Zn2+ in Zn x ZrO may be the active site for the targeted C–H bond cleavage of ethane. For Zn x ZrO catalysts, their C2H4 yield were ordered: Zn0.2ZrO > Zn1ZrO > Zn0.1ZrO > Zn0.05ZrO > Zn0.02ZrO (Fig. 7(b)). The C2H6 conversion, C2H4 selectivity, and C2H4 yield over Zn0.2ZrO were 19.1%, 54.9%, and 10.5% within 5 h, respectively, and the C2H4 yield was about 4 times that of pure ZrO2. The C2H4 selectivity monotonically increased with the increase of the Zn/Zr molar ratio (Fig. 7(c)), suggesting that the Zn-O-Zr sites formed by doping Zn2+ are the active sites for selectively breaking the C–H bond of ethane. In addition, the change trend of CO2 conversion was consistent with the relative concentration of OV (Fig. 7(c) and Table S2), and the maximum CO2 conversion was obtained over Zn0.2ZrO, indicating that the OV was responsible for activating the C=O bonds of CO2. However, the C2H4 yield of Zn1ZrO was reduced, which was caused by the presence of massive ZnO covering part of the active sites. The above results revealed that Zn0.2ZrO had the maximum amount of Zn-O-Zr active sites and OV. In addition, the properties of the catalyst after a long reaction were studied by characterization. The XRD patterns of fresh and spent Zn0.2ZrO were compared to study the changes in the catalyst (Fig. 8(a) ). Similar diffraction peaks could be observed before and after the reaction, and these characteristic peaks were attributed to t-ZrO2, so the crystal structure of Zn0.2ZrO remained stable during the reaction. Notably, the diffraction peak intensity and peak width of the spent Zn0.2ZrO catalyst became stronger and wider, indicating that the average grain size increased significantly after the CO2-ODHE reaction. According to the Scherrer equation, the average grain size increased from 27 to 72 nm. The grain growth covered the active sites of the catalyst, which may lead to slow deactivation of the catalyst. The carbon deposition is then quantified by TG analysis (Fig. 8(b)). The weight loss rate of Zn0.2ZrO after 5 and 42 h were 3.78% and 13.92%, respectively, indicating that the carbon deposition increased with the increase in reaction time. XPS spectra of fresh and spent Zn0.2ZrO were used to study the element valence states change before and after the reaction (Fig. 9 ). The wide-scan XPS spectrum showed that fresh and spent Zn0.2ZrO were composed of Zr, Zn, and O elements (Fig. 9(a)), indicating that the composition of the catalyst did not change obviously. However, the characteristic peak intensities of Zr 3d and Zn 2p decreased significantly after the reaction (Fig. 9(a)), meaning that the Zn-O-Zr sites were covered by carbon deposition after a long reaction time. The corresponding reduction of peak area also verified this conclusion (Figs. 9(b) and (c)). The curve-fitting XPS spectrum of Zr 3d and Zn 2p revealed that no Zr0 and Zn0 ions were formed after the reaction, that is, both metals still exist in oxidation state. Notably, compared with fresh Zn0.2ZrO, the Zr 3d peak of spent Zn0.2ZrO shifted to a higher value, which was related to the depletion of OV [ 31 ]. The relative concentration of OV was quantitatively calculated by O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 9(d)), which decreased from the initial 0.32 to 0.23 after the reaction, indicating that OV directly participated in the CO2-ODHE reaction process. The catalytic performance of Zn0.2ZrO was compared with other catalysts reported in the literature (the specific reaction conditions and performance values are shown in Table S3) (Fig. 10(a) ). In particular, using C2H4 STY as a basis for performance evaluation, the C2H4 STY of 797.6 μmol/(min·g) within 5 h was obtained over the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst, which was at the leading level compared with the catalysts reported in the literature. In addition, the apparent activation energy of Zn0.2ZrO was 91.9 kJ/mol by kinetic calculation (Fig. S3), which was lower than some other catalysts reported in the literature (Fig. 10(b)). The results indicated that the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst reported in this paper has prominent advantages in terms of catalytic performance (especially the C2H4 STY). 3.4 Reaction mechanism Prior research indicates that during the catalytic dehydrogenation of low carbon alkanes (C2–C4), coordination unsaturated Zr cations (Zrcus) and lattice oxygen in ZrO2-based catalysts were the active sites for breaking C–H bonds [ 69–71 ]. Thus, the active sites for breaking C–H bonds over the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst were determined by CO pretreatment and HNO3 pretreatment experiments, and their catalytic properties were tested (Fig. 11 ). In theory, the ability to release lattice oxygen becomes stronger with the increase of CO reduction temperature, and more Zrcus will be formed [ 31 ]. In fact, the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield decreased (Fig. 11(d)), suggesting that Zrcus may not be the active site for ethane dehydrogenation. Raman results showed that the vibration modes associated with OV (582 cm–1) weaken with the increase of CO reduction temperature and even the signal completely disappeared at 600 °C (Fig. 11(a)), indicating that OV was related to ethane dehydrogenation activity. The HNO3 pretreatment experiments were used to further analyze whether Zn2+ was related to the activation of C–H bonds (Figs. 11(b) and (c)), and the removal rate of Zn2+ was quantitatively calculated by XPS spectra (Table S4). The content of Zn2+ decreased gradually with the increase of HNO3 pretreatment time, correspondingly, the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 yield also decreased (Fig. 11(e)), suggesting that the presence of Zn2+ was closely related to the C–H bonds activation of C2H6. Some studies have also shown that the acid–base properties of the catalyst were related to the dehydrogenation activity of ethane [ 72,73 ]. Py-IR and NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 6) showed that Zr4+ was partially replaced by Zn2+ to form the new medium strong acid sites (Zn-O-Zr sites). The concentration of the medium strong acid sites increases with the increase of the molar ratio of Zn/Zr (except Zn1ZrO, due to some sites being covered by the bulk phase ZnO) (Fig. S4(a)). The C2H4 selectivity is positively correlated with the concentration of the medium strong acid sites (except Zn1ZrO), indicating that the Zn-O-Zr sites may be the main active sites for selectively breaking the C–H bond of ethane. In addition, the OV is considered to be the active site for activating the C=O bonds of CO2 [ 74,75 ]. According to O 1s XPS analysis (Fig. 5(c)), the content of OV increased with the increase of the molar ratio of Zn/Zr (except Zn1ZrO). Among them, the content of OV in the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst is the highest, and the maximum CO2 conversion is obtained over the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst (Fig. S4(b)). The above results suggest that the CO2-ODHE reaction over Zn x ZrO catalysts may involve the tandem reaction mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation on the Zn-O-Zr sites and RWGS on the OV. The reaction mechanism over Zn0.2ZrO catalysts was determined by in situ FTIR spectra (Fig. 12 ). In the first stage, when the reaction atmosphere was C2H6:N2 = 1:3, the C–H and C=C stretching vibrations peaks of ethane and ethene were observed in the range of 2870–3000 cm–1 (Fig. 12(a)) [ 77 ]. This indicated that C2H6 was activated and undergoes direct dehydrogenation to form methyl or ethyl fragments. In the second stage, the reaction atmosphere was switched to CO2:N2 = 1:3, the C–H and C=C stretching vibrations peaks disappeared completely, while the O–H stretching, the vibrations peaks of CO2 and the HCOO* stretching vibration appeared clearly in the range of 3550–3750 and 2280–2380 cm–1, respectively (Fig. 12(b)) [ 28,77–78 ]. This revealed that the intermediate HCOO* species was formed by the RWGS reaction between CO2 and the by–product H of the dehydrogenation of ethane. In order to approximate the real reaction conditions, in the third stage, the reaction atmosphere was switched to C2H6:CO2:N2 = 1:1:2, the C–H and C=C stretching vibrations, the O–H stretching, and the HCOO* stretching vibration peaks appeared at the same time (Fig. 12(c)). In addition, the weak peaks in the range of 1000–1700 cm–1 belonged to the species HCOO*, HCO3*, and H3CO*, which may be related to the intermediates reacted by the adsorption of hydroxyl and CO2 on the catalyst surface [ 76 ]. This demonstrated that in the co-reaction of C2H6 and CO2, the first dehydrogenation of ethane occurred to produce ethylene and byproduct H, and then CO2-assisted removal of byproduct H to form HCOO* intermediates, and then formic acid intermediates was formed to generate CO and H2O, which desorbed to gas phase, resulting the regeneration of the active sites in turn. This process was consistent with the two prerequisites of tandem catalysis proposed by Zhang et al. [ 79 ]: (1) the product H of ethane dehydrogenation can be immediately transferred to the RWGS reaction as the reactants, and (2) in the CO2-ODHE reaction system, ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS are two independent catalytic cycles, these cycles occurring in different sites. In summary, the CO2-ODHE reaction over Zn x ZrO catalysts followed the ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS tandem mechanism, which was different from the Mars-van-Krevelen redox mechanism of CO2-ODP catalyzed by Zn x Zr1–x O2–x solid solutions reported in the literature [ 80 ]. However, since Zn x ZrO were metal oxide catalysts, the existence of Mvk mechanism cannot be completely excluded. In order to further verify the above reaction mechanism, the C2H6 conversion and C2H4 selectivity of the Zn0.2ZrO during the C2H6 pulse were analyzed (Fig. 13 ). Compared with a normal reaction atmosphere (C2H6:N2 = 1:3 vs. C2H6:CO2:N2 = 1:1:2), the C2H6 conversion decreased rapidly and the C2H4 selectivity increased during the first pulse, indicating that the by-product H produced by the ethane direct dehydrogenation could not react with CO2 in time, and would occupy the active sites of the catalyst, resulting in a rapid decline in activity. Notably, the C2H6 conversion increased after regeneration in CO2:N2 = 1:3 atmosphere, indicating that CO2 could assist the removal of by-product H through RWGS reaction, which was conducive to the recovery of the active sites, and effectively promote the balance of ethane dehydrogenation to move forward. In situ FTIR analysis also proved that H reacted with CO2 to form HCOO*, which promoted the desorption of H and ensured the time-flow stability of ethane dehydrogenation. However, the C2H6 conversion still has a certain irreversible loss after 4 times of CO2 regeneration, because the carbon deposits cannot be completely removed by the reverse Boudouard reaction, resulting in irreversible poisoning of the active sites. Therefore, combined with the in situ FTIR conclusions, it is clear that the reaction over the Zn x ZrO catalyst mainly follows the mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of Zn x ZrO bifunctional catalysts were prepared by adjusting the Zn/Zr molar ratio, and the functions of two types active sites were found by in situ techniques and ethane pulse experiment: the medium-strength Lewis acid sites (Zn-O-Zr sites) selectively breaks the C–H bonds of ethane, while the strong Brönsted basic sites (oxygen vacancies) effectively activates the C=O bonds of CO2. The CO2-ODHE reaction over Zn x ZrO catalysts primarily follows the tandem reaction mechanism involving ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS. Namely, the direct dehydrogenation of ethane produces C2H4 and by-product H over the Zn-O-Zr sites, then CO2 reacts with H to form formic acid intermediates over the OV, and finally the formic acid intermediates are dissociated to CO and H2O, while the Zn-O-Zr active sites are regenerated to complete the reaction cycle. The Zn0.2ZrO catalyst exhibits the best catalytic activity and initial C2H4 STY (355.5 μmol/(min·g)), and the C2H4 STY remained stable at 325.7 μmol/(min·g) within 5 h. This study not only prepared a bifunctional catalyst that upgraded both ethane and CO2 into high value–added products, but also provided a catalyst design idea for light alkanes to break C–H bonds purposefully to light olefins. coredata.dc:description: The CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (CO2-ODHE) provides a promising way to produce ethylene and utilize CO2. Simultaneous upgrading of ethane into the high value–added chemical products and the reduction of greenhouse gas CO2 emissions could be achieved. However, the targeted breaking of the C–C/C–H bonds of ethane is still a challenge for the designed catalysts. In this paper, ZnO-doped ZrO2 bifunctional catalysts (Zn x ZrO) with different Zn/Zr molar ratios were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method, and the functions of various sites for CO2-ODHE reaction were revealed by in situ characterizations and ethane pulse experiment: the medium-strength acidic Zn-O-Zr sites are responsible for the purposefully cracking of ethane C–H bonds to ethylene, while the more oxygen vacancies (OV) created by the introduction of Zn2+ are responsible for the efficient activation C=O bonds of CO2, thus promoting the RWGS reaction. In addition, the Zn0.2ZrO catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic performances, with C2H6 conversion, C2H4 yield, and CO2 conversion about 19.1%, 10.5%, and 10.6% within 5 h, respectively (600 °C, GHSV = 3000 mL/(g·h)). Especially, the initial ethylene space-time yield of 355.5 μmol/(min·g) was obtained under 6000 mL/(g·h); Finally, the tandem reaction mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation and RWGS was revealed.

coredata.dc:title: Synergistic sites over the Zn x ZrO catalyst for targeted cleavage of the C–H bonds of ethane in tandem with CO2 activation
